direct_answer.text: First, let's treat Pierre, Rosa, and Thomas as a single unit since they insist on sitting next to each other. Now we essentially need to arrange four entities: [Pierre, Rosa, Thomas] group and five individuals separately. There are ($[5]$, $[P\&R]$)*($4!$) arrangements because ([Peter],([Paul & Rose]))*the permutations amongst themselves equals ((either Peter or Paul)+(Either Robert or Rachel))*(number of distinct permutations among them i.e., 4!) However, keep note that within our grouped set; [(Pierre, Rosa, Thomas)] could switch places internally resulting in another arrangement thus multiplying it further by (*$3!$). Hence overall possibilities would be *${(5)}$*{$(4!)$}*$({$(3!)})$= ${!(60)}=.720.$ As rotational seating equates identical positional assignments thereby dividing original count by six leads us ultimately landing onto .$\mathbf{12}$. Thus ,there exists **12** unique circular placements fulfilling said criterion. The answer is: 12.

Now arrange them along with another 5 distinct persons who do not need any specific arrangement beside themselves forming six entities [(XPT),(Person)]*[(Another Person)], [...]]*(One more Person)].  
This represents selecting spots out of available ones without considering order because sitting next to each other does not matter within XPT itself. Thus it reduces our problem into arranging six items taking up five places leaving us nine extra spots spread evenly over twelve positions including those already taken leading to combinatorial choice problems i.e., choose k=5 places out of n=12 - {seated} giving rise permutation possibility calculated using binomial coefficient formula : $$\binom{n}{k}=C(n,k)=\frac{n!}{(n-k)!k!} $$ Here , n equals eleven due to exclusionary approach . Substituting back yields ;$$\binom{11}{5} =\frac{11!\cdot(11-5)!5! }{5!(

direct_answer.text: Considering both sides of Pascal Triangle Odd Numbers Equation using above hint yields ${\displaystyle {{70}\times {\begin{pmatrix}8 \\ 3\end{pmatrix}}}={{70}\times \,{\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}\hline {}&{}&{}&\text{Central Term}&{:}\\ &\left({\binom{7}{2}}\right)&{\binom{7}{2}}&{\binom{7}{2}}&\\ &&\vdots &{:}\\ &&&&\hfill \,\binom{1}{1}\,\quad\,\,\,\\ \end{array}}=70\cdot \begin{bmatrix}21&21&21&\\ &&&\\ &&\underline{1}&\\ \end{bmatrix}}$ Hence required permutations according to condition become equal to multiplication obtained when applying central term methodology giving us `${70*21}` i.e., `$`**1470`.
